Our democracy is strong, but the work to protect it is never done. @HouseDemocrats are committed to working with President Biden to better our nation and continually strive toward "a more perfect Union.‚Äù

In his address, President Biden highlighted the possibilities of our great nation when we work together and when we stand united. And, it is the resilience of the American people that continues to make America so great.
As Members of Congress, we have a responsibility to meet the demands of these times and to work tirelessly for the American people and their interests.

He called upon Congress to strengthen the middle class, fix our infrastructure, safeguard Social Security and Medicare, enact gun violence prevention legislation, protect reproductive freedom, uphold our promise to veterans, and create a fair economy that works for all Americans.
We heard from the President on his agenda to uplift America‚Äôs working families, make our communities safer, and make the limitless opportunities that our country has to offer accessible to all.

And to all of my colleagues who may have disagreed with the president at some point last night but refrained from embarrassing our country by shouting at him... 

you get no congratulations because that's the bare minimum we should all expect.

What will the Outrage Olympics bring us today?

No one knows. But *we all know* that it won't make our country stronger. It's not built for that. 

It's built to exploit people who have been trained to see politics only through the lens of anything-goes political combat.

It's a big reminder of the weird incentives that exist in Congress for a handful of people to find new lows.

It wasn't about any policy disagreement. They were just auditioning for very specific kind of attention from certain media outlets.

And... it probably worked.

Imagine you were with us on the House floor last night, sitting amongst hundreds as tens of millions watch at home.

Now imagine how unlikely it would be that you would ever think, "Oh, this is when I should start yelling at the president."

What I keep forgetting is that there is simply a completely different incentive structure for some folks here. 

They are rewarded for turning politics into the Outrage Olympics and trying to out-compete each other every single day.

It's wild to see in person.

While we were on the House floor waiting for the State of the Union to start, we took bets on whether there'd be any heckling.

In retrospect, I was a too optimistic. There was plenty.

There were dozens of bipartisan proposals in his speech, and we should work together on them.
